712765f-a.text:
(1)
East 42nd Street, north side, west from the East River, showing piles of old street car rails on an empty lot, and farther west the 23-story Prospect tower, on the east side of Prospect Place, between 42nd and 43rd Streets. In the background is visible the Chrysler
Building, at the N.E. corner of Lexington Ave.
March 31, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A detail of No. 1, viewing slightly northward, showing across the piles of old street car rails the north side of East 43rd Street, west to First Ave. These buildings are all units of the United Dressed Beef
Co., a meat supply dorporation.
March 31, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

712766f-b.text:
East 42nd Street, north side, at the East River, viewing northward, showing the abattoirs and meat packing houses there. Beyond are the apartment houses constituting the Beekman Hill and Sutton Place residential areas. The latter nestles at the foot of the Cueensboro Bridge.
Sept. 28, 1940
Panaorama set; 1-2
P. L. Sperr

710765f-b.text:
Twelfth Avenue, north across West 42nd Street, showing the West Side Vehicular Highway under construction. View 2 details the pedestrian activity on 42nd Street. The individuals shown are moving eastward after their arrival on the Weehawken Ferry from New Jersey. No. 3 is similar to View 1, showing completion of structural
work at this point.
1-2: May 30, 1934
3: Oct 20, 1939
P. L. Sperr

713022f.text:
42nd Street, west across Fifth Avenue (foreground)as photographed from the Lincoln Building. Bryant Park and the New York Public Library on the left, face the 500-Fifth Avenue Building, Salmon Towers, Aeolian Hall and Stern Brothers Department Store. The 6th Avenue "El" station
appears st the top.
1938-9
Alexander Alland
This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume "Portrait of N. Y.' by Felix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.

717936f-c.text:
(1)
Bryant Park, center and west side, towards 42nd Street, giving a rear view of the Federal Hall replica, on which demolition
is beginning.
April 8, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same view, but closer to 42nd Street, showing the Park being remodelled under the regime of Commissioner Robert Moses, New ork's first city-wide Commissioner of Parks.
March 15, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same, seen from the south side, and showing the Park after completion of the work. The flower beds are planted with
ivy.
The large corner building, at Sixth Avenue and 42nd Street, is
the department store of Stern Brothers.
July o. 1V35.
P. L. Sperr.
